case_name: Collector of Bombay v. Municipal Corporation of the City of Bombay

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree of Bombay High Court (Sen and Dixit JJ.) dated 21st February 1947 in First Appeal No. 64 of 1943.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from a judgment and decree of the High Court of Bombay  Sen and Dixit JJ.  dated 21st February, 1947, in First Appeal No. 64 of 1943.

facts.text: Revenue Judge at Bombay delivered judgment on October 27, 1942, dismissing suit filed by respondents (Municipal Corporation and Municipal Commissioner) against Collector of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: against the judgment of the Revenue Judge at Bombay delivered on October 27, 1942, in a suit filed by the respondents, the Municipal Corporation of the City of Bombay, and Madusudan Damodar Bhat, the then Municipal Commissioner for the City of Bom- bay, against the Collector of Bombay.

facts.text: No substantial dispute as to facts leading up to litigation.

anchor.surface_text: There is numbersubstantial dispute as to the facts leading up to this litigation and they may be shortly stated.

facts.text: In 1865, Government of Bombay decided to construct Eastern Boulevard and called upon Corporation of Justices of the Peace (predecessor of respondent Corporation) to remove fish and vegetable markets.

anchor.surface_text: In 1865, the Government of Bombay, having decided to companystruct an Eastern Boulevard, called upon the Corporation of Jus- tices of the Peace for the City of Bombay, the predecessor in title of the respondent Corporation, to remove its then existing fish and vegetable markets from the site required for the companystruction of the Boulevard.

facts.text: Municipal Commissioner Arthur Crawford applied for site on Esplanades for new markets.

anchor.surface_text: The then Municipal Commissioner Mr. Arthur Crawford, after whom the present municipal market was named, applied for the site set aside for the exhibition buildings on the Esplanades for the pur- pose of companystructing new markets

facts.text: On December 5, 1865, Architectural Improvement Committee informed Government no objection to site of about 7 acres being rented to Municipal Commissioner at one pie per square yard.

anchor.surface_text: On December 5, 1865, the Architectural Improvement Committee informed the Government that it had numberobjection to the proposed she measuring about 7 acres being rented to the Municipal Commissioner and suggested that the annual charge of one pie per square yard be levied

facts.text: On December 19, 1865, Government passed resolution approving grant of site without rent as markets for benefit of community.

anchor.surface_text: On December 19, 1865, the Government passed the fol- lowing resolution -- Government approve of the site and authorise its grant. ... Government do number companysider any rent should be charged to the Municipality as the markets will be, like other public buildings, for the benefit of the whole companymunity.

facts.text: Possession of site given to Municipal Commissioner pursuant to 1865 Resolution, but no formal grant executed as required by Statute 22-23 Vic. C. 41.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the aforesaid Resolution, possession of the site was made over to the then Municipal Commis- sioner, but numberformal grant was executed as required by Statute 22 23 Vic. C. 41.

facts.text: Municipal Commissioner filled up and leveled site at Corporation's expense; plans approved, market buildings erected at considerable expense.

anchor.surface_text: The Municipal Com- missioner had the site filled up and leveled at the expense of the Corporation. The plans were approved by the Govern- ment and the market buildings were erected by the Corpora- tion at companysiderable expense.

facts.text: Respondent Corporation incorporated in 1888 as successor of Corporation of Justices of the Peace.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Corporation was incorporated in 1888 as the successor of the Corporation of the Justices of the Peace for the City of Bombay

facts.text: Corporation continued in possession without paying rent per 1865 Resolution for over 70 years.

anchor.surface_text: and it companytinued in possession of the land and the buildings with- out paying any rent to the Government according to the Government Resolution of 1865.

facts.text: Corporation spent Rs. 17,65,980-12-1 up to March 31, 1940 on filling, leveling, erecting and maintaining market.

anchor.surface_text: It is in evidence that besides giving up the sites on which the old markets had been situate, a total sum of Rs. 17,65,980-12-1 has been spent by the Corporation up to March 31,1940, in filling up and leveling the site and erecting. and maintaining the new market buildings on this site.

facts.text: In 1911, portion of market site acquired for widening Palton Road; Collector/Superintendent City Survey stated Government had no claim, Corporation received full compensation.

anchor.surface_text: In 1911, a portion of the market site was acquired by the Government for the widening of the Palton Road. Upon the Collector of Bombay being called upon to put in ,his claim, if any, to any part of the companypensation money awarded by the Land Acquisition Officer, the Superintendent,, City Survey, on behalf of the Collec- tor, replied that Government had numberclaim in respect of the said land.

facts.text: On March 18, 1938, Collector informed Municipal Commissioner of proposal to assess land under section 8 Bombay City Land Revenue Act 1876.

anchor.surface_text: On March 18, 1938, the appellant Collector of Bombay informed the respondent Municipal Commissioner that it was proposed to assess the land occupied by the Crawford Market under section 8 of the Bombay City Land Revenue Act II of 1876

facts.text: Municipal Commissioner replied site given as gift, no assessment.

anchor.surface_text: In his reply, the Municipal Commissioner wrote to say that the site of the market had been given to the Municipal- ity as a gift for the companystruction of the market and that, therefore. the question of assessment did number arise.

facts.text: On March 23, 1939, Mayor wrote to Government asserting permanent rent-free grant intended.

anchor.surface_text: the Mayor of Bombay on March 23, 1939, wrote a letter to the Government stating, inter alia, as follows -- The Corporation have been advised that there can be numberdoubt that it was the intention of Government to make a permanent grant of the land to the Municipality, and, fur- ther, that it was also the intention that permanent grant should be free from rent and from assessment to land reve- nue.

facts.text: Government repudiated contentions on January 1, 1940, stating right to levy assessment is prerogative not destroyed by non-user.

anchor.surface_text: The above companytentions were repudiated by the Govern- ment in its letter of January 1, 1940, in the following terms- As regards the companytention that the land has been held by the Municipality uninterruptedly for over 70 years with- out any suggestion from Government that it was liable to assessment, I am to state the right to levy the assessment is the prerogative of the Crown and a mere number-user of this prerogative cannot destroy it.

facts.text: On January 31, 1940, Collector assessed land under section 8: Rs.7500 first 10 yrs from Apr 1 1940, Rs.15000 next 10, Rs.30000 remaining 30 yrs.

anchor.surface_text: On January 31, 1940, the appellant Collector assessed the land under section 8 of the Bombay Act II of 1876 with a guarantee of 50 years as under -- Assessment Rs. 7,500 per annum for the first 10 years from 1st April, 1940. Assessment Rs. 15,000 per annum for the next 10 years. Assessment Rs. 30,000 per annum for the remaining 30 years.

facts.text: Suit filed in Revenue Judge court for declaration of right to hold land without assessment and to set aside assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The present suit was thereupon filed in the Court of the Revenue Judge in accordance with the provisions of the Bombay City Land Revenue Act, 1876, for the following reliefs, inter alia ---  a  that it may be declared that there is a right on the part of the plaintiff Corporation in limitation of the right of Government to assess the said land

facts.text: Revenue Judge dismissed suit on October 27, 1942 with costs.

anchor.surface_text: By his judgment dated October 27, 1942, the learned Revenue Judge dismissed the suit with companyts.

facts.text: Bombay High Court reversed Revenue Judge, declared rights of Corporation, awarded costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the High Court reversed the decision of the learned Revenue Judge, allowed the appeal and passed a decree declaring the rights of the respondent Corporation and awarding to it the companyts in both Courts.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal heard October 5, 1951; Das J read judgment, Sastri and Aiyar separate judgments.

anchor.surface_text: 1951. October 5. The Judgment of Kania CJ., Das and Bose JJ. was read by Das J. Patanjali Sastri and Chandrasekhara Aiyar JJ. delivered separate Judgments.

facts.text: Government Resolution of 1865 invalid as grant or contract due to non-compliance with Statute 22-23 Vic. C.41; not challenged.

anchor.surface_text: two of the learned Revenue Judges companyclusions were number challenged. namely,  1  that the Government Resolu- tion of 1865 was-bad in law either as a grant or even as a companytract and companyld number by itself operate to give any inter- est in the land

facts.text: Corporation in possession over 70 years under invalid grant, acquired title by adverse possession to hold free of rent for market purposes.

anchor.surface_text: This possession has companytinued openly, as of right and uninterruptedly for over 70 years and the respondent Corporation has acquired the limited title it and its predecessor in title had been prescribing for during all this period, that is to say, the right to hold the land in perpetuity free from rent but only for the purposes of a market

facts.text: Das J held respondent has right in limitation of Government's right to assess per s.8 Bombay Act 1876; appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, for reasons stated above, the actual decision of the High Court was companyrect and this appeal should be dismissed with companyts, and we order accordingly.

issues.text: whether, on the facts of this case, the respondent Corporation has succeeded in establishing in itself a right in limitation of the right of the Government to assess the land in consequence of a specific limit to assessment having been established and preserved

anchor.surface_text: The sole question for our consideration is whether, on the facts of this case, the respondent Corporation has succeeded in establishing in itself a right in limitation of the right of the Government to assess the land in consequence of a specific limit to assessment having been established and preserved.

issues.text: whether the respondent has established a right to such exemption

anchor.surface_text: The only question, therefore, is whether the respondent has established a right to such exemption.

issues.text: whether such principle [Ramsden v. Dyson] should be extended to the facts of the present case, whether the facts of this case attract the application of the equity established in Ramsden v. Dyson supra or attract the equity established in Maddison v. Alderson and Walsh v. Lonsdale

anchor.surface_text: There has been considerable discussion before us as to the precise scope and effect of the principle of equity enunciated in Ramsden v. Dyson supra , as to whether such principle should be extended to the facts of the present case, whether the facts of this case attract the application of the equity established in Ramsden v. Dyson supra or attract the equity established in Maddison v. Alderson 2 and Walsh v. Lonsdale 3

issues.text: whether, in view of the decision of the Privy Council in Ariff v. Jadunath 1 , the equity in Ramsden v. Dyson supra can prevail against the requirement of formalities laid down in the Victorian Statute

Dyson supra can prevail against the requirement of formalities laid down in the Victorian Statute referred to above any more than the equity in Maddison v. Alderson supra can do against the requirements of the Transfer of Property Act

anchor.surface_text: No question of estoppel by representation arises, for the Government made numberrepresen- tation of fact which it number seeks to deny. Nor can any case of estoppel by acquiescence be rounded on the facts of the case. Both parties knew the facts and neither was misled.

arguments.claim: Lost grant presumption does not extend to presume Crown deprived itself of prerogative to tax.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant submits that in the circumstances a lost grant should be presumed, and that this lost grant should be presumed to have companytained an exemption from land revenue or a right in limitation of the right  1   1937  64 I.A. 334. of Government to assess the property. The law may presume the existence of a grant which has been lost where it is sought to disturb a person in the enjoyment of right which he and his predecessors have immemorially enjoyed, but it is a different thing to seek to presume that the Crown has by some lost grant deprived itself of the prerogative power to tax the property of its subjects,

arguments.claim: Rent in 1865 Resolution means assessment; representation acted upon, Government estopped from going back.

anchor.surface_text: In the first place, there can be little doubt that the word rent in paragraph 2 of the Government Resolution of the 19th December. 1865, means assessment . It is true that this word is used generally in cases of landlord and tenant, but when it is remembered that here the Govern- ment was parting with the land vested in the Crown in favour of the Municipal Corporation of Bombay, it can safely be assumed or presumed that they were thinking number merely of their rights as landlord but also of their prerogative right as well.

arguments.claim: Government representation no rent charged as markets for community benefit; acted upon, equity/estoppel prevents retraction.

anchor.surface_text: When the Architectural Improvement Committee proposed to levy a numberinal rent, the Government stated that numberrent need be charged, as the markets to be built were for the benefit of the whole companymunity. This was a representation made by the Government when the site was given and possession was taken.

arguments.claim: Resolution reads as rent-free grant, within estoppel s.115 Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: If the resolution can be read as meaning that the grant was of rent-free land, the case would companye strictly within the doctrine of estoppel enunciated in section 115 of the Indian Evidence Act.

holdings.text: The Government Resolution of 1865 was bad in law either as a grant or even as a contract and could not by itself operate to give any interest in the land.

anchor.surface_text: Before the High Court, as before us, two of the learned Revenue Judges conclusions were not challenged. namely,  1  that the Government Resolu- tion of 1865 was-bad in law either as a grant or even as a contract and could not by itself operate to give any inter- est in the land

holdings.reasoning_summary: Non-compliance with formalities required by Statute 22-23 Vic. C.41 for Crown dispositions; conceded by parties.

holdings.text: The respondent Corporation has acquired the limited title by adverse possession to hold the land in perpetuity free from rent but only for the purposes of a market.

anchor.surface_text: This possession has continued openly, as of right and uninterruptedly for over 70 years and the respondent Corporation has acquired the limited title it and its predecessor in title had been prescribing for during all this period, that is to say, the right to hold the land in perpetuity free from rent but only for the purposes of a market

holdings.reasoning_summary: Possession under invalid grant prima facie adverse from inception, continued openly as of right uninterruptedly over 70 years, prescribing for specific limited interest per resolution terms.

holdings.text: The immunity from the liability to pay rent is an integral part of the title acquired by adverse possession, constituting a right in limitation of the Government's right to assess under section 8.

anchor.surface_text: The immunity from the liability to pay rent is just as much an integral part or an inseverable incident of the title so acquired as is the obligation to hold the land for the purposes of a market and for no other purpose. There is no question of acquisition by adverse possession of the Governments prerogative right to levy assessment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rent immunity inseverable from limited title acquired; prerogative assessment distinct but limited by perfected title incident.

holdings.text: Section 8 of Bombay City Land Revenue Act applies to cases of total exemption where specific limit is nil.

anchor.surface_text: It is true, as pointed out by the Privy Council in Karnalavahooji Maharaj Collector of Bombay  supra  that the words of the section would appear to apply rather to the case of a limitation on the right to assess than to the case of a complete exemption from assessment but such a construction would not protect the cases of total exemption which, as conceded in that very case, did in fact exist and were recognised and protected by virtue of the words of section 8 of the Bombay Act II of 1876.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Words cover total exemption per Privy Council concession in Karnalavahooji; protects existing nil limit cases.

holdings.text: Appellant cannot raise distinction between rent and land revenue as not pleaded below or raised in courts below.

anchor.surface_text: It was sought to be argued that even if the Government be precluded from enhancing the rent in view of the terms of the Government Resolution, it cannot be held to have disentitled itself from its prerogative right to assess land revenue. This contention is sought to be founded on a distinction between rent and land revenue. This contention, however, was not raised in the written statement and was not made the subjectmatter of any issue on which the parties went to trial and was never put forward before either of the Courts below.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No pleading, issue or argument below; Mayor's letter equates rent/revenue not denied.

holdings.text: High Court decision correct; appeal dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, for reasons stated above, the actual decision of the High Court was correct and this appeal should be dismissed with costs, and we order accordingly.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of above determinations upholds respondent's right under s.8.

holdings.text: Respondent has not established right to exemption from assessment; resolution invalid and unenforceable.

anchor.surface_text: The only question, therefore, is whether the respondent has established a right to such exemption. The resolution of the Government dated 19th December, 1865... did not by itself purport to pass title to the land in question or to confer on the Municipality a right to exemption from land revenue. Admittedly no formal instrument was executed

holdings.reasoning_summary: No formal instrument per Statute 22-23 Vic. C.41; dissent.

holdings.text: No application of Ramsden v. Dyson equity or part performance against statutory formalities.

anchor.surface_text: There is, in my opinion, no room here for the application of the principle of Ramsden v. Dyson 1 . That decision has been explained by the Privy Council in Ariff v. Jadunath 2  as based on the equitable doctrine of part performance which, their Lordships held, could not be applied so as to nullify the express provisions of the Transfer of Property Act relating to the creation of leases.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Privy Council in Ariff limits equity to not override formal statutes; dissent.

holdings.text: No estoppel by representation or acquiescence.

anchor.surface_text: No question of estoppel by representation arises, for the Government made no representation of fact which it now seeks to deny. Nor can any case of estoppel by acquiescence be founded on the facts of the case. Both parties knew the facts and neither was misled.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No misleading fact; conduct referable to unenforceable agreement; dissent.

holdings.text: Adverse possession extinguishes property right under Limitation Act s.28 but not prerogative right to levy land revenue.

anchor.surface_text: But the right to levy land revenue was not part of the Governments right to the property. It is a prerogative right of the Crown which was placed on a statutory basis under the Bombay City Land Revenue Act of 1876, and could be exercised in respect of a land only on the footing that it belonged to another, the superior holder,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessment exercised recognizing other ownership; prerogative distinct; dissent.

holdings.text: Lost grant presumption does not extend to exemption from prerogative revenue right.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant submits that in the circumstances a lost grant should be presumed, and that this lost grant should be presumed to have contained an exemption from land revenue or a right in limitation of the right  1   1937  64 I.A. 334. of Government to assess the property. The law may presume the existence of a grant which has been lost where it is sought to disturb a person in the enjoyment of right which he and his predecessors have immemorially enjoyed, but it is a different thing to seek to presume that the Crown has by some lost grant deprived itself of the prerogative power to tax the property of its subjects,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cannot presume Crown surrendered tax prerogative; per Privy Council; dissent.

holdings.text: Word 'rent' in 1865 Resolution means assessment; Government estopped from retracting representation acted upon.

anchor.surface_text: In the first place, there can be little doubt that the word rent in paragraph 2 of the Government Resolution of the 19th December. 1865, means assessment . It is true that this word is used generally in cases of landlord and tenant, but when it is remembered that here the Government was parting with the land vested in the Crown in favour of the Municipal Corporation of Bombay, it can safely be assumed or presumed that they were thinking not merely of their rights as landlord but also of their prerogative right as well.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Context of Crown land parting includes prerogative; acted upon; concurring observation.

anchor.surface_text: in view of the decision  1   1931  L.R. 58 I.A. 91.  2   1905 I.L.R. 29 Bom. 580. of the Privy Council in Ariff v. Jadunath 1 , the equity in Ramsden v. precedents.citation: Goswamini Shri Kamala Vahooji v. Collector of Bombay 1

anchor.surface_text: A somewhat analogous question arose in Goswamini Shri Kamala Vahooji v. Collector of Bombay 1 . The Government admitted that no land revenue had ever been charged in respect of the land which was enjoyed by the holders for more than a century without payment of revenue and it was urged that in virtue of such a long enjoyment a lost grant of the land on the terms that it should be held free from liability to pay revenue must be presumed.

precedents.case_name: Goswamini Shri Kamala Vahooji v Collector of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: no presumption of lost grant including revenue exemption from long enjoyment
precedents.cited_holding: lost grant cannot deprive Crown of prerogative to tax

anchor.surface_text: The immunity from the liability to pay rent is just as much an integral part or an inseverable incident of the title so acquired as is the obligation to hold the land for the purposes of a market and for no other purpose. There is no question of acquisition by adverse possession of the Governments prerogative right to levy assessment.

In our opinion, for reasons stated above, the actual decision of the High Court was companyrect and this appeal should be dismissed with companyts, and we order accordingly. PATANJALI SASTRI j.--I am of opinion that this appeal should

It is true, as pointed out by the Privy Council in Karnalavahooji Maharaj Collector of Bombay  supra  that the words of the section would appear to apply rather to the case of a limitation on the right to assess than to the case of a complete exemption from assessment but such a construction would not protect the cases of total exemption which, as conceded in that very case, did in fact exist and were recognised and protected by virtue of the words of section 8 of the Bombay Act II of 1876.

anchor.surface_text: There is, in my opinion, no room here for the application of the principle of Ramsden v. Dyson 1 . That decision has been explained by the Privy Council in Ariff v.
